title: Will the book “Superforecasting" (2015) be on the New York Times Bestseller's list by the end of October?
preds: Whooo hoo! I'm mad that I went from 95 - 75 on Oct. 6, but such as life.
if it got this far by the 9th, momentum is favorable to be in the top 10 in 22 more days(10/31)
Revised based on NYT listing of sales activity.  Guess a lot of forecasters bought it.  It is very enlightening.

It's a 15-, not 10-book list.  We shouldn't just ask whether Aziz will fall, though, but also what's the sales of 1944, the book just below Superforecasting -- and relative extent to which it's willing to game the system with bulk orders and such. Simon & Schuster have a book on the list, Crown doesn't.

Really couldnt see this one.  Even with hindsight my best case would have been moderating to be less wrong.  Biggest error seems to be the ebook category,  i only thought of the misc. How to was a risk.  Oh well.  Onwards and upwards.
Doh! I should have known my purchase was the tipping point!
Appears on the list. Probably pointless to estimate. Good book btw.
But if they gamed it, will it make it up one more spot, or is that it?

Anyone care to guess what my Brier score on this one will be from this picture: https://larswericson.wordpress.com/2015/10/09/my-voting-record-on-will-the-book-superforecasting-2015-be-on-the-new-york-times-bestsellers-list-by-the-end-of-october/
Following einsteinjs, thanks to his link to the best-seller list showing it at #11. Move up just one and the questions closes.
Revising from 97 to 100. As others have said -- it's on the list --> http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-18/e-book-nonfiction/list.html
It's on the Ebook Nonfiction (#11) and the Print & Ebook Nonfiction (#16) lists now.

#11 on E-book non-fiction list. http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-18/e-book-nonfiction/list.html A bit surprised it didn't make the hardcover list after looking at the Amazon sales figures. Last week was really strong for it, at least on Amazon.  I guess the correlation is not 100%, or the lag time is greater for NYT bestseller hardcovers.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/08/us-mideast-crisis-intelligence-exclusive-idUSKCN0S20CZ20151008 Congress confronts Spy agencies over late Syrian intell.  Go get 'em Congress.
Got mine today. It reads pretty well. A deserving place.

Well, I'll be... 
Congratulations are in order, I suppose. But I never really doubted it!😅

Following @NickLutz
There have been a lot of well-placed articles in the last two weeks.

It's in: http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-18/combined-print-and-e-book-nonfiction/list.html A lot closer than I thought, but hey, a win's a win.  I don't know if the question will be resolved now or when the list goes into print, but either way, it should be a yes.
Following Gjdrew. Even if the scorers discard the Nov. 1 list on the basis of a technicality, there is a chance for the Oct. 25 list to make it.

1-3 odds. It's the type of book that makes the list, but it's a very short timespan for it to rise. It's a bought-not-read book, and the genre is crowded (too many "The Signal and the Noise"-type books) without being in actual high-demand. I will be changing this if Tetlock makes it on a TV show.
Moving up 2% from 8% because of the good review in the Economist.  But I still think there's a lot of "since I am interested in this, then most others will be too" bias.
and thanks to @000 and @GJDrew, back up we go
Gjdrew has me worried,  moving up so i am not completely wrong.
Convinced by the comments by GJDrew, 000, and others, I'm shifting slightly positive.

I take it back.  Those NYT lists are weekly, and we don't have to worry about tail off.   Last week, Superforecasting did quite well (22-51), better than Aziz Ansari (#10) did a week before that, and almost reaching Plunder and Deceit level (#7).  I'm projecting Superforecasting to come at #9 now on the next list. http://www.novelrank.com/asin/0804136696
http://www.novelrank.com/asin/1594206279
http://www.novelrank.com/asin/1451606303 I think it's in.

Moving up after reading 000's post.  Comparing the NYT list against Amazon rankings: http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-11/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html Tahesi Coates, #4 on NYT hardcovers.  #42 on Amazon list.
Atul Gawande, #5 on NYT.  #95 on Amazon list.
David Brock, #10 on NYT.  #1315 on Amazon list.
Aziz Ansari, #11 on NYT.  #189 on Amazon list.
Mary Karr, #12 on NYT.  #213 on Amazon list.
Suzy Favor Hamilton, #13 on NYT.  #777 on Amazon list.
Rick Bragg, #14 on NYT.  #421 on Amazon list.
David Maraniss, #15 on NYT.  #343 on Amazon list.
Erik Larson, #16 on NYT.  #292 on Amazon list.    
Jewel, #17 on NYT.  #548 on Amazon.
Ian Toll, #18 on NYT.  #403 on Amazon. Superforecasting has been in the 30-180 range on the Amazon list for the whole period.  It's #188 now.  The main competitors I see are: Bernanke's book and Billy Graham's book, both new and above Superforecasting right now on the Amazon list. I think the projection is probably around #12 on the next NYT list.  The main concern is if it plunges in Amazon rank over the next week or so.  If it stays above #200, it's pretty sure to make it.  Even if it stays above #300, it'll probably squeak in.

The current bottom of the Non-Fiction Hardcover list is My Fight/Your Fight. [1]  This is #454 in Amazon Books.    Tetlock's book is #183 in Amazon Books.  So I give it a shot, it's simple math.  If there is a correlation of 1 between positions on Non-Fiction hardcover and Amazon Books rank, our guy's book should end up in the top 5 or so. [1] http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-11/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html

Looking at Warren Hatch's Sept. 1 forecast, he makes the point that the last release of a new NY Times bestseller list before the end of the month would be Oct. 25. The actual wording of the question appears to be whether it will "Be on...list by the end of October," rather than have sold enough copies by the end of October to be reported on the list to be released Nov. 1. So if the scorers follow the exact wording, they will say, oops, too bad, you were a few minutes late... Would they do it in such a not picking way? My earlier power players analysis led me to believe they would be sensible and admit that the Nov. 1 report of October sales would fit the criteria. But now I'm not feeling so certain, given the scorers' dogged refusal to give any clarifications.
The book seems potentially of interest to a wide swath of the public. But end of Oct. coming soon.
Reading the book now.    Good but technical discussion may be less attractive for some readers (but yes, important content.)
People love stats more and more.
Most likely not, only enlightened people like this stuff as we all know most Americans are brain dead.
Good media coverage but too many more interesting (to the general public) titles are out in general non-fiction.
End of October will be here soon.  The book and Dr. Tetlock seem to continue to get good media coverage.
reducing the last 2% based on #JAL link.

If it didn't make it when sales were at peak I doubt it will now....
http://www.novelrank.com/asin/0804136696
Sorry, I meant to keep my forecast the same for now, counting upon the facts and behaviors of the scorers having a happy and productive confluence.

Regarding Delorean's well researched analysis, given the "clarification-free" problems on this site, I can see his concerns. However, a power player analysis suggests that the scorers should be motivated to judge this question on the basis of the actual facts of October sales rather than having a secret agenda of only counting earlier sales. Power players analysis: The scorers: While an actual facts forecast would require that the scorers should  wait for the October sales figures to arrive, they might have really meant the September sales alone. If so, all of us forecasting above 50% now are screwed. Tetlock: On the other hand, given that the lead author of this book has a financial stake in this competition, I imagine that he would be outraged if this question was not fairly judged. The publishers: They know how to play the bestseller lists. The book has been issued simultaneously in hardcover, paperback, MP3 CD and ebook formats. The reviewers: Staggeringly wide and favorable coverage of the target audience.
"Tetlock's thesis is that politics and human affairs are not inscrutable mysteries. Instead, they are a bit like weather forecasting, where short-term predictions are possible and reasonably accurate... The techniques and habits of mind set out in this book are a gift to anyone who has to think about what the future might bring. In other words, to everyone."
—The Economist "One of the best books I've read this year... Superforecasting is a must read book."
—Seeking Alpha "In this captivating book, Tetlock argues that success is all about the approach: foresight is not a gift but rather a product of a particular way of thinking... In each chapter, the author augments his research with compelling interviews, anecdotes, and historical context, using accessible real-world examples to frame what could otherwise be dense subject matter. His writing is so engaging and his argument so tantalizing, readers will quickly be drawn into the challenge - in the appendix, the author provides a concise training manual to do just that. A must-read field guide for the intellectually curious."
—Kirkus Reviews, starred "[An] important new book... [from] the scholar of the science of prediction."
—Times of London "We now expect every medicine to be tested before it is used. We ought to expect that everybody who aspires to high office is trained to understand why they are so likely to make mistakes forecasting complex events... Politics is harder than physics but Tetlock has shown that it doesn't have to be like astrology."
—The Spectator “Philip Tetlock is the world expert on a vital subject. Superforecasting is the wonderful story of how he and his research team got ordinary people to beat experts in a very serious game. It is also a manual for thinking clearly in an uncertain world. Read it.” 
—Daniel Kahneman, winner of the Nobel Prize and author of Thinking, Fast and Slow

“The best way to know if an idea is right is to see if it predicts the future. But which ideas, which methods, which people have a track record of non-obvious predictions vindicated by the course of events? The answers will surprise you, and they have radical implications for politics, policy, journalism, education, and even epistemology—how we can best gain knowledge about the world. The casual style of Superforecasting belies the profundity of its message.”
—Steven Pinker, Johnstone Professor of Psychology, Harvard University, and author of The Better Angels of Our Nature

“In this accessible and lively book, Tetlock and Gardner recognize the centrality of probabilistic thinking to sound forecasting. Whether you are a policymaker or anyone else who wants to approach decisions with great rigor, Superforecasting will serve as a highly useful guide.” 
—Robert E. Rubin, Former U.S. Treasury Secretary

“How well can we predict the future, really? There is no better way to answer that question than to read this book. You will come away disillusioned about the ability of experts, but also enlightened about how the best forecasters do it—and maybe even hopeful about your own prospects.”
—Tyler Cowen, Director of the George Mason University Mercatus Center and author of Average Is Over 

“For thousands of years, people have listened to those who foretold the future with confidence and little accountability. In this book, Tetlock and Gardner free us from our foolishness. Full of great stories and simple statistics, Superforecasting gives us a new way of thinking about the complexity of the world, the limitations of our minds, and why some people can consistently outpredict a dart-throwing chimp. Tetlock’s research has the potential to revolutionize foreign policy, economic policy, and your own day-to-day decisions.”
—Jonathan Haidt, New York University Stern School of Business, and author of The Righteous Mind

“Superforecasting is a rare book that will make you smarter and wiser. One of the giants of behavioral science reveals how to improve at predicting the future.”
—Adam Grant, New York Times bestselling author of Give and Take 

“Good judgment and good forecasting are rare, but they turn out to be made of teachable skills. By forcing forecasters to compete, Tetlock discovered what the skills are and how they work, and this book teaches the ability to any interested reader.”
—Stewart Brand, President, The Long Now Foundation

“Philip Tetlock is renowned for demonstrating that most experts are no better than ‘dart-throwing monkeys’ at predicting elections, wars, economic collapses and other events. In his brilliant new book, Tetlock offers a much more hopeful message, based once again on his own ground-breaking research. He shows that certain people can forecast events with accuracy much better than chance—and so, perhaps, can the rest of us, if we emulate the critical thinking of these ‘superforecasters.’ The self-empowerment genre doesn’t get any smarter and more sophisticated than this.”
—John Horgan, Director, Center for Science Writings, Stevens Institute of Technology

“Superforecasting is the rare book that is both scholarly and engaging. The lessons are scientific, compelling, and enormously practical. Anyone who is in the forecasting business—and that’s all of us—should drop what they are doing and read it.”
—Michael J. Mauboussin, Head of Global Financial Strategies, Credit Suisse

“There isn’t a social scientist in the world I admire more than Phil Tetlock.”
—Tim Harford, author of The Undercover Economist

“From the Oracle of Delphi to medieval astrologers to modern overconfident experts, forecasters have been either deluded or fraudulent. For the first time, Superforecasting reveals the secret of making honest, reliable, effective, useful judgments about the future.”
—Aaron Brown, Chief Risk Officer of AQR Capital Management and author of The Poker Face of Wall Street

“Socrates had the insight in ‘know thyself,’ Kahneman delivered the science in Thinking, Fast and Slow, and now Tetlock has something we can all apply in Superforecasting.”
—Juan Luis Perez, Global Head of UBS Group Research

Revising downward after looking harder at the NYT list publishing cycle and this question's closing date. I think there's a very good chance that Superforecasting will appear on the monthly "Business" list, but that list reflects the prior month (the Oct list "reflects sales in September"), etc. I don't think that the list will be published in time to fulfill the question. Also, the NYT Reviews are behind the publishing curve. The just published (on Oct. 2) a review of Salman Rushdie's new novel, which came out on Sept. 8. The Oct. 11 list was published today -- http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-11/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html -- but only reflects sales through Sept. 26. I think the timeframe should be extended or the question should be rephrased to something like "Will the book 'Superforecasting' be on the New York Times Bestseller's list that reflects sales through the end of October?" In lieu of that clarification, I'm going to change my prediction from 95% to 75%. I still think it has a very good chance to appear on one of the next 3 weekly lists that will be posted before Oct. 31, but don't want to get destroyed on the Brier score.
Not widely known or broadly interesting. Also October is fast passing by
slight adjustment up based on recent press and dominich's analysis, but still skeptical.

Superforecasters as of 10/5/15 is number 65 on Amazon nonfiction ebook bestsellers.  Into Thin Air, the last book on NYT ebook list, is showing number 34 on that same Amazon list, extrapolating I would infer that Superforecasting is somewhere around #20 on the NYT ebook list if it extended past 10 (a rough guess).  
Amazon list here "link":http://www.amazon.com/Best-Sellers-Kindle-Store-Nonfiction/zgbs/digital-text/157325011#4 Perhaps more promising that inspecting the NYT ebook list, 5 of the 10 books have only been on the list 1 week, and 3 for 2 weeks, implying that it is a transitory list that has a bit of volatility from week to week.  So it seems reasonable that a book currently at number ~20 could make jump 10 spots in the next 3 lists, especially given that the book is still in the early stage with mainstream media reviews trickling in.
It has fallen to about 46 on Amazon, so it now seems less likely.
Too heady and specialized. No sex, violence, or political ranting.
The broader significance of this kind of forecasting may attract wider audiences.
As much as I enjoy reading it, Amazon has the book listed under Technology as the #1 best seller.  There is no comparable category in New York Times best sellers.
Raising this, based on the positive comments (e.g. by Dominich), even though I'm not fully convinced into going positive.
The book, Dr. Tetlock and the GJP have been getting a fair amount of media attention.

More great publicity today. From an email from a friend who just read the Sunday Review, a magazine provided by the NYTimes and read avidly by book lovers around the nation:
Carolyn, Interesting article re your judgment tournament in Today's NYTimes:  The Power of Precise Predictions by Tetlock, Gardner and Scoblic, p. 10. Sunday Review.
Upping a bit, article in Forbes may help sales.

The odds of any book making list is low. I did a google trends search and superforecasting didnt register and even under google news there werent that many stories. Also I thought the book was great and every book on the NYT bestsellers list is lame
amazon sales reported at novel rank are lower than I had expected even though the rankings indicate that the book is "popular and sales are underreported"
There's a nice review in Forbes today.
I have been disappointed that it was not ranking higher on Amazon (#144) but dominich's analysis gives me hope.
I think I need to try to get my average to 50% and then park there.  The more I watch, the less sure I am that this is going one way or the other.
Following Dominich's well documented and analyzed forecast discussion.

Most appropriate comparison class seems to be books in the current NYT Top 20 Hardback Non-fiction (=NYT HBNF) bestsellers. Given compilation dates, Superforecasting (currently ranked #1 Best Seller in Business & Forecasting by the US Amazon site) could appear here in the chart published online  next week (and in 18 Oct print edition of NYT reflecting sales for week ending 3rd Oct)	= see note at bottom of http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-10-11/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html  11 of top 20 are #1 Best Seller in a section labelled by Amazon ( 20 - Mixed Martial Arts; 19 – National & International Security; 18 – Naval Military History; 17 – Pop Artist Biographies; 15 – Music History & Criticism; 14 – Essays; 8 – Christian Ministry & Church Leadership; 7 – Political Parties; 6 – Transportation History; 5 – Health Policy; 4 – Sociology of Race Relations) 13 of the top 20 NYT HBNF were published in September 2015, showing that it is plausible for a newly published book to be ranked in this chart: of these one (no 19) was published on 1 Sept, one (no 8) on 8 Sept, seven (nos 2, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17) on 14 or 15 Sept, four (nos 1, 3, 9, 18) on 21 or 22 Sept/ More significantly “Superforecasting” is Amazon #147 best seller in Books.
While there is clearly not a direct correlation between sales on amazon.com and those sellers surveyed for the NYT HBNF list (this is evident as the no 10 book on the NYT list is only ranked 2,803 on Amazon's chart, far lower than the remainder of the top 20 – the book at number 20 is ranked #368, and all but three of the top 20 (nos 19, 18, 10) are in Amazon's top 1,000, while 15 of the top 20 are in the top 500. Seven of the top 20 (nos 1, 2, 4, 3, 5, 6, 7) are ranked more highly than “Superforecasting”.  If this is an accurate point of comparison, and next week's book market is broadly similar to this weeks  it seems reasonable to foresee “Superforecasting” ranked somewhere in the lower part of the top 10 of the NYT Hardback Non-fiction chart next week. Main counterarguments: lack of correlation between Amazon sales and those at sources included to compile NYT HBNF list, this one chart surveyed for some reason not being typically representative.

It is not readers of the NYT (or for that matter The Economist, which just ran a favourable review) who determine what's a best-seller.  Placement on the Times' list is not an award for being a good book, it's pretty straightforward reporting on actual sales.
Oh yes it is. Perfect for hurricane or stormy weekend reading... => http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/04/opinion/the-power-of-precise-predictions.html
See?  I know little, but @000 knows alot...
Per @criminel, I'm giving it a shot.

Check it out, linked from the home page of the New York Times. This is perfectly placed for weekend reading and book buying, and should boost the prospects of this book. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/04/opinion/the-power-of-precise-predictions.html
Moving up on the basis of Nick Lutz's data and analysis.
Probably too many other mind-wasters to compete against....
Revised indicators and it is a far better subject to be a best seller

There are multiple lists and it only needs to get on one.   This book has been at or above 150 on Amazon all week.  A small fraction of the Amazon top 100 are non fiction hardcover books (a lot are kids books, cook books, fiction, etc).  All the hardcover books I noticed that were ranked higher than Superforecasting were either on the NYT Hardcover Nonfiction list's top 6 (out of 20), or, were just released a few days ago (like Superforecasting) and will not be eligible for the NYT list for a week or so.  Seems to be beating the Business list too. My best guess is that it'll end up around the 10-12 spot in Hardcover nonfiction.  Should almost certainly be in the top 20.  My only uncertainty is that the NYT methodology is somewhat of a black box to me and I'm not a book publishing nerd so I could be missing something.  But from a reference class stand point, this looks like a slam dunk. Any reason why this shouldn't be an 80%+ type question?
Given the GJP audiance may create some volume early on, suspect that if the early numbers don't make the list, it may become less likely later.

Decreasing rating after seeing more info that it will be in the nonfiction categories of hardcover or e-book.
I had placed a higher rate if it were to be in the business subcategory, but there are simply too many great non-fiction books that were released in September and I don't think the marketing efforts were all there.
Going down on my prediction. This was probably a mistake to forecast.  I know little about the attributes of NYT Best Sellers. Now I must study.
And perhaps I'm right, but I'll just sit here for a day or so, first.

Reaffirming my previous forecast that it is improbable that this question will resolve positively, and becoming more seriously pessimistic regarding its chances. As an aside, my copy is waiting at home, and Amazon emailed me to let me know that the price had fallen by $1.43. Law of supply and demand I suppose....
Pulling back closer to my original forecast after it slipped at Amazon (#118 today). The best seems over. Will change again if there's a flicker.

I was hoping to see a review by David Brooks and see it zoom up.  There's many positive blurbs out about it and it is doing well, but doesn't seem to be doing spectacularly.  So, I'm going to moderate my forecast.

Couldn't find it on amazon, so as per previous getting rid of the wobble and reducing from 12 to nominal.  As before, only real chance is if they categorise in the "Advice, how to and misc" section, then may be toast, but that's not my bet as to where they categorise it.
One very much fears that on this as on some other Qs, people are voting their wishes rather than their steely-eyed predictions.
Following 000 and GJDrew and their information sources and analyses.

Amazon's #2 Best Selling Book is "Rush Revere and the Star-Spangled Banner" by Rush LImbaugh. [1]   So think about it, people:  Prof. Tetlock is super, but the market's appetite is for children's stories by Rush Limbaugh featuring Rush Limbaugh.  So if the NYT list is driven by the market, being super may just not be enough. [1] http://www.amazon.com/best-sellers-books-Amazon/zgbs/books/ref=pd_dp_ts_b_1

Definitely upping the prediction, not sure if it can make it in the time frame. Reason for the update is Amazon's overall  ranking at #136 (10-2-2015) and #1 in their  "Business & Money > Management & Leadership > Planning & Forecasting" --Granted we are looking at subcategories of subcategories, but it does have a chance...

amazon rankings...wow
two more positive reviews in media since I last adjusted up, so adjusting up further.
The Amazon lists are very fluid.  It's not staying on the Top 100, so going back to my original cautiously optimistic.
It's right now at 121 on books.  Very likely to end up on the NYT bestseller list, but might not make it within the timeframe.
It's 39 on Amazon. Not bad for two days after release.
Bumping up to 97% from 96%. Just a heads up: from what I know, the NYT bestseller list tracks from Sun-Sun, so we should see an update to the list at the beginning of next week.
Updating based on Amazon data below...
I got this far based on the Economist review plus the fact that I ordered the book.  However, who reads the Economist anyway?

The subject is too technical and academic compared to what usually makes it to this list. I can't see how many copies are sold for the books that make the list nor the number of copies sold so far of "Superforecasting", but taking  Amazon customer reviews as a proxy they are generally well below of what can be found on the books on the bestseller list.
Is it true 11,000 sales can put you on the NYT bestsellers list? How many of us are in this competition? There could be a fair number of sales from just us.

Holding.  I bought a hard-cover from my local independent bookstore, Books Inc, today.  It had decent placement on the shelf. It pushed McGonigal's Super Better, which came out 2 weeks ago, to the bottom shelf.  McGonigal is pretty popular in the Bay Area. The first copy on the stack seemed to have been thumbed through (spine was cracked open a bit).   Whether that means people thumbed through it and decided not to buy it, or it's good that people were willing to thumb through it remains to be seen.

I'm increasing my odds a bit based on recent news.  There is an interesting correlation problem for this question; the success of the GJOpen Tournament and of this book are presumably related.  Thus, your forecast matters more if Superforecasting is on the NYT Bestsellers List then if it isn't.  This should lead to general overestimation.

The book is doing great in Amazon.  I put 97 because I wish the book sells well...this is my bias.

#1 in Books > Medical Books > Psychology > Cognitive
#1 in Books > Science & Math > Behavioral Sciences > Cognitive Psychology
#1 in Books > Business & Money > Management & Leadership > Planning & Forecasting
#17 on amazon day before release date.
He is a bright and pleasant person and it is a good book.  Many good books written by bright and pleasant people do not make the Times list.
Several of my friends have said that they'd like a copy, and of course, my Mom wants one, so I'm ordering a bunch today.
The Economist led with the story about the book in this week's edition. Those who would be interested in the book are probably Economist subscribers. Their book reviews are influential.

http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/books/1364796/whats-best-predict-future/ "Superforecasting is a very good book. In fact it is essential reading - which I have never said in any of my previous MT reviews."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This is a very nice book review.  I've already had one friend remark that they thought they had read about the book in the WSJ over the weekend.  Amazon shows it as 64th (or 20th?).
Positive press in the WSJ and it's the #64 bestseller overall on Amazon... I think it's going to make it.
Yes, thanks to the WSJ article mentioning it.
The subject is highly relevant to nearly everyone; the author is a well respected social scientist; the book is highly readable suitable for mass consumption; the marketing apparatus seems in place.
OK per Einstein it's gonna happen.
Bumping up from 88% to 96%. Have a hunch that it might debut on NYT bestseller list.
Reaffirming my previous forecast and hedging down slightly. Greatest concern is the ability with such a short timeframe to generate the velocity of sales needed to get to the best seller's list.

First Sale?
 Picked up and paid for my pre- ordered copy of "Superforecasting" this evening at Barnes & Noble.
Interesting pre-launch article in The National Post on 27 Sept will help fuel sales (though admittedly more so in Canada than in the U.S.).

Trying not to be a hedgehog. but moving up to  80%, because of two very positive book reviews:
Seeking Alpha     http://seekingalpha.com/article/3535796-tetlock-and-gardner-superforecasting
The Economist    http://www.economist.com/news/books-and-arts/21666098-forecasting-talent-luckily-it-can-be-learned-unclouded-vision
It got a very good review on "Seeking Alpha", and the current rank on Amazon is 32.

Moving up slightly as some of the high forecasts are making me wobble, even though I remain convinced it will not break in.  My basis remains that I think the book will be categorised as a business book and as such it will have to feature in the non fiction category (these need thousands in a week, not the hundreds to get onto Amazons list); that said,  I could be toast if they put it in the Advice, How to & Miscellany category.  I don't see it getting into the monthly categories for business in the timeframe, as the question requires it to be on a list in October and the October monthly sales are only published in November.    It is not able to get into the best sellers list until 18th October as the results are backward looking by two weeks.   For that week (18th), it has not sold the full week, it has taken from 29th - 3rd, but it is its opening salvo (but even on amazon overall it is not getting out of the 20's and their bar is very low).  On balance, and on the basis it will be in non fiction, saying it wont likely make it.  Then 4-10th Sept is next big shot.  Will modify upwards if the Amazon rankings skyrocket between now and then.

Historically, it's a fantastic time to launch a book, as it's before the holidays, and there's a bit of a lull in the industry.  The book's been making headway on blogs (Economist, Seeking Alpha) and is #1 across multiple Amazon categories (which doesn't factor into the NYT list, but is still a good indicator).  Non-fiction is traditionally the largest and most profitable market aside from children's, and Tetlock's got the rep, the social proof and the track record to back it up.
The WSJ bump will be significant.

Moving up a bit more since it's already #20 on Amazon's book list, and #5 on Amazon's business book list.  Publicity moves very fast... I have access to a program that receives advance copies for review, and this book went out of stock quickly. Pre-release sales on Amazon are strong. Sorry, this forecast is pulled completely out of my hat. No citations. Just apologies.
Keeping in mind:
1.	this is an accessible book, written in layman’s terms, co-written by a journalist (good writer) that can be understood without expert knowledge in Tetlock’s field
2.	it is a kind of self-improvement, skill development book about a topic that applies to so many people’s fields and interests, it appeals to a wide variety of people
3.	AND it is coming out in Christmas shopping season
4.	There are several other books on Amazon about forecasting, there is interest in this topic.
5.	A book needs to sell about 4000 copies in one week to get on the NYT best selling booklist. (caveat-completely unsubstantiated statistic, found on an author’s blog)
6.	I have read numbers between 3000 and 10000 participants in GJP. Human curiosity being what it is, many of them will want to buy a copy. Just to see what Mr. Tetlock says about the project they were involved with. Especially those of us now participating in GJ Inc.  Wannabe superforecasters like me want to glean helpful info. If half of GJP participants go buy the book when it first comes out, there is a good possibility one week could see over 4000 copies bought, between participants and general public.
7.	Media articles about forecasting and GJP have put forecasting on the public’s radar. (Even I heard about it by 2014, and my teenagers will tell you I am the least likely, uncoolest person to know anything that’s trendy.)
Although many might be interested in the topic, few will actually read the book.

If they've managed to "sell" it to Amazon that is a great start & it's visibility and the awareness consumers have of it will only increase.

There's only 17 days until it will be released.   Is interest in it building?  I think so.   It seems that some books explode and hit the lists right away, while others get a slow start but keep growing steadily.  I have no idea which this book will be.  So much depends on unknowns:  will David Brooks @ NYT review it?  when?  Will FT?  How much PR will Crown be doing?   On the up-side:
1)  Most early reviews of it are really positive.  It's definitely getting positive press.
2)  sales are up.  I note that on http://www.novelrank.com/asin/0804136696 there's a "footnote" on the recent sales number (19 in Sept) which says, "Due to high popularity, this sales estimate is low; actual sales are much higher"  How much higher is "much higher"??? because 19 sales sure doesn't seem to be enough to me!
3)  A bookstore owner looked up the initial print run for me and said that it was 100,000, which he said meant that the publisher's confidence in it was high.   I assume that the advertising/promotion budget will be high, as well.  I hope that the money is well-spent!  
4) I read the first excerpt of it that is posted at http://www.scribd.com/doc/277483466/Superforecasting-by-Philip-E-Tetlock-and-Dan-Gardner#.VfRVrOk0r05 and found it an engaging and enjoyable read.  I can see why one reviewer said this book was as close as a non-fiction book comes to being a page turner. For those of us who participated in the GJP study, it is hard to approach this question without hope and a bias.  This "forum" is a bit of a bubble or echo chamber, as well, and that adds another layer of "noise" that I've tried to filter out.  I worry that I may have over-compensated for what I acknowledge is my hope that it sells well, and my obvious interest in the subject.  I think it is time that I "flipped" my forecast.

Well, guess what:  Trump's book "In Pursuit of Success" will come out the week before "Superforecasting".  I don't see an upside to this for "Superforecasting".  Just as Trump the Candidate has sucked up all the air in the Republican party presidential campaign, Trump the Writer will suck up all the airtime for book reviews.

What does it take to get on the NYT bestseller list?  Here's what I've learned:
-not every book bought counts.  NYT counts only some sellers' sales.  Grocery stores probably don't count, but independent booksellers' sales get extra weight. Airport sales may not count.
-a sales peak during one week is all that's needed because the counts are weekly.  Every week is a new race.
-if the book physically ships out of the book seller’s warehouse weeks before the pub date, it goes from “pre-order” status to “sold” — and thus, it does not get counted in launch week
-bulk orders are weighted differently.  If this book is used as a textbook, not every sale will count
-500-1,000 sales are needed to hit Amazon's list, and the NYT list is assumed to require 10x that:  5-9k
-there's seasonal variations, so the bar raises & lowers.  January is a slow month for sales; Sept is a high one
-a ton depends on what other books were released at the same time/what the competition is.  I've been unable to figure out what other books in its category will be released in Sept.
-the bar is lower/higher in different NYT list categories COMMENT:  I pre-ordered a copy last spring from Amazon; if it ships early it may not count.  I think I may order additional copies from my local indie, one each day.

I do not think the book will be on the NYT bestseller’s list by the end of October. Firstly, one month from publishing to the deadline is really too short. However, this does not exclude the book to be on the list after the deadline. Secondly, the book really does not fit the profile of books on the list of NYT bestseller’s list in non-fictional over the past few months (biography, personal achievement, historical, political or business Leaders accounts/ideas…).

anninak's report of a 100K print run means the publisher will do all the right things to get on the best seller list. If the past is prologue, even if many from this 100K print run end up as returns, the scoring mechanism won't account for this. I could be wrong on the scoring mechanism now in place, hence on 85%.

100k are being printed, so the publisher seems to be betting on it.

It's unlikely to be on the general nonfiction list.

The public will become more widely aware of GJP with release of the book because of widespread media coverage. Thoughtful citizens will be curious about understanding the world better. I did not make it higher because I'm concerned that many adults, especially in the US, do not understand the world through personal critical review. Many listen and follow what their infotainment of choice says. Will enough Americans be curious or is the majority following political pipers?

I am not sure enough people are aware of the book or interested in the subject matter for it to gain the necessary popularity.  Also, the amount of time remaining for this to happen is growing short.  It does have good editorial reviews so will keep and eye on this event.

Good reviews, and several of them. Publisher is also a known and trusted quantity. In view of current global uncertainties, and autumn being a time of year in which "serious" books for a general audience have traditionally performed well, I think there is a reasonable chance of this. I have not yet checked out what competition it may be up against, however. Being involved here does also present a bias, however.
Good early reviews, but will it grab the public's interest?
Current events likely increasing people's sense of uncertainty in the world and the book seems to be getting some reasonable visibility so far.
With a banner political year, many will want to understand and even learn how people forecast and the  super forecasting title would seem to draw people in
Phil and the rest of the GJP team are awesome.  Enough said.
Just because I want something doesn't mean it will happen :)
In an highly politicized environment (2016!) interest in such topics -- especially with a "gamified" tilt may be strong.
We have a biased interest in this relative to others

The best comparison for "Superforecasting" is probably "The Signal and the Noise" by Nate Silver.  "The Signal and the Noise" was published on September 27, 2012, and made it to the NYT bestseller list on October 28th.  That suggests an average time of a month to make the list, or a 50% chance of making the list before the end of October (since "Superforecasting" will be released on September 29th).  However, I don't think that "Superforecasting" will be quite as popular or successful as "The Signal and the Noise" (which seems to be the strongest book in its category, and thus hardly a typical case).  I give it a 25% chance of being that successful, for a 12% chance of being on the bestseller list by the end of October.
From what I understand the book only needs to be at the top of it's category.  It doesn't directly compete with the latest fiction novel.
While it may generate sales as a business book over time, don't think it will make an immediate splash.   Looking forward to reading it though!
In reading through some of the comments, I think my initial prediction of 39% was still too optimistic. Revising down.
Too narrow a topic; too narrow a timeframe. "Bought with" books on Amazon are lucky to get above 4000. Pre-ordered mine with the GJP stipend.

Here is Crown's give-away raffle promo:  http://www.readitforward.com/giveaway-predicting-the-future-with-superforecasting/ "From one of the world’s most highly regarded social scientists, a transformative book on the habits of mind that lead to the best predictions." "Transformative"? Would you buy a book that promised you transformation? I'm reading the book  with the understanding Tetlock did not write this promo.  I question Crown's cheesy write-up.

Gaming bestseller lists is an industry unto itself (http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2013/02/22/heres-how-you-buy-your-way-onto-the-new-york-times-bestsellers-list/).
I would love to see it happen, but intuition says "not a wide enough audience".  Let's have a show of hands amongst all of us, the early beta-testers of GJP II.  How many are going to buy? Having said all of that,
How does a bestseller happen? http://fourhourworkweek.com/2007/08/06/how-does-a-bestseller-happen-a-case-study-in-hitting-1-on-the-new-york-times/

It seems common for authors of this kind of niche book to get on various main-stream media (TV)/syndicated media (Radio) outlets BEFORE the official release of the book.  I have not seen/heard the good professor on any segments as of yet.  Getting on at least one major mass audience outlet seems like a prerequisite for getting on "The List". In a Google search I could find no reference to anything current. I dont think it is too early for Dr Tetlock to create a big enough buzz for the book.  Has the window passed for this question to close as a "yes"?   I think if he gets on a headline show then the odds increase dramatically.

Base case: I checked latest NYT 15 non-fiction books. One (Jimmy Carter's) had 59 reviews on Amazon; the next lowest was about 150 reviews; it went all the way up to a few thousand. In contrast, Tetlock's "Expert Political Judgement" has only 34 reviews since 2006. I can;t see why the new book would do spectacularly better.
GJP audience: I don't see a huge audience among the GJP participants. If 20,000 took part in GJP, about half hardly participated (based on my 10-person group sample). Of the others, I doubt more than 15% will actually buy the book. And, many of those are probably the type who will put it on their list and get to it, as part of their reading.
Finally, the subject-matter is a step removed from being personally actionable. The idea that crowds have wisdom is interesting, but it is not enough motivation for most readers to invest the time in knowing more than a high-level summary.

I understand it takes about 10,000 sales within a week for a book to get on the NYT Bestseller list. The GJP and Tetlock have been getting media coverage over the last few years and are probably well known by now among people interested in the subject. However, my simplistic approach is to say that there were 20,000 participants in GJP's Season 4, and a large proportion of them are going to buy the book, many may have pre-ordered it already. I think there's a strong likelihood that the book will show up on the Best Seller List in the first week after release.

Joining at the high end at 66%. Apparently, the list is updated every Sunday, so last available date this year is 25 October ... presumably they do the final tally a day or two earlier, maybe Friday at the end of the business week, which is 23 October. Just over 3 weeks to surge in the ranks. I think it happens. Here's the nonfiction list for the last Sunday of October last year:
http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2014-10-26/combined-print-and-e-book-nonfiction/list.html Of the top 15, if I'm reading Amazon right, 6 (or 40%) came out inside our timeframe: Not That Kind of Girl (30 Sep 14), The Innovators (7 Oct 14), Being Mortal (7 Oct 14), Stop the Coming Civil War (7 Oct 14), Worthy Fights (7 Oct 14), Rocks (7 Oct 14). Another 2 were pretty close: Killing Patton (23 Sep 14) and What If (2 Sep 14). Another way to get a base rate is with similar titles that also had an enormous amount of publicity on release. For one, Daniel Kahneman's Thinking Fast and Slow came out on 2 Apr 13 and was on the NYT list by 20 Apr 13, inside our timeframe. 
http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2013-04-20/combined-print-and-e-book-nonfiction/list.html
Lot of hype around the book, but October is not enough time.

While this has been categorized as a "Just For Fun" question, I suspect it might actually end up being more difficult to forecast than some of the geopolitical questions. Given our intense closeness to the topic, well, I'll speak solely for myself. Given MY intense closeness to the topic of forecasting, it's hard to get a gauge for how well the general public (or more specifically, the NYT bestseller list) might receive this book. While I'd certainly like to see it make the list, from my cursory Google searches in the doldrums this summer, my inkling is that there's a smaller chance than folks are forecasting at this point.  Of course, this could completely change when it comes time for Tetlock/Gardner to do the press tour.

-if a major columnist  writes about it, like David Brooks (hasn't he already written about GJP?), that would make a huge difference

1. Superforecasting comes out September 29.

So Superforecasting has only a month to get on the list.   2. Here are the possible lists it could show up on:
- COMBINED PRINT & E-BOOK NONFICTION
- HARDCOVER NONFICTION
- E-BOOK NONFICTION those are weekly lists. The monthly lists don't seem relevant. 3. It is being published by Crown, which has one book on the nonfiction list(s) currently.  4. But it is a top "hot new release" at Amazon in a small niche -- not even tops in business. This includes pre-order info.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/new-releases/books/3/ref=zg_bsnr_unv_b_2_2689_2 5. This could be before a push by Crown, a traditional publisher. I am just starting with a favorite number, obviously, but I do believe this is less than 50% chance.

I just went with 99 percent on this one.  This might be a rookie mistake, not being used to non-market-based platform.  But my rationale is based on the thought that Dr. Tetlock's other book for a popular audience, on expert judgement, was a best seller; he's gotten ample positive press on his ground-breaking research since then; and since this question really concerns how strong early buzz on the book would be vs. it's objective quality, I'd say it will get a lot, lot of positive word-of-mouth from the 1,000s of folks who've volunteered for the Good Judgment Project before now--many of whom are liable to be influential in getting others to read, and at least some of whom (me) post a lot about this stuff to Facebook, where people can read about it and get interested.  I might be over-confident about my hit-picking skills for non-fiction, but I did post the Economist's article on Picketty's Capital in the 21st Century to Facebook when they reviewed it in French, and said how eager I was to read the English translation.

Malcolm Gladwell has several books on the NYTB currently, including Outliers ~7 years after it was released. I anticipate that Superforecasters could fit into the Gladwell/Silver niche for popular social science with obvious real world applications. I'm hedging because I'm not sure that there's all that much mainstream interest in this -- e.g. there have been 1,700 NYT articles that have mentioned "Malcolm Gladwell," compared to 0 that have mentioned "superforecasting," 3 with "Good Judgment Project" (only 1 since 2012), and 53 that have mentioned "Tetlock."
Four weeks to get on the list. Will revisit forecast after the first week to see how the buzz is.
people are interested in the subject. A short time frame to be #1 but with publicity it could do it

It's a significant book, and it's the type book that appeals to a segment of Times Readers.  The time frame is short, but the book is getting, and will get a lot of buzz. The conclusions are novel enough to attract readers, and many people are interested in forecasting.
I don't think that's enough time to make it.
Given the attention it's already getting and the publisher's influence that's putting it out, it's pretty safe to assume it will do quite well.
The advance buzz is great, and the book is already on the Financial Times long list for Best Business Book of 2015.
May not be as interesting to people outside of a too narrow group. I don't think the genre is out of steam yet, but the bar for writing quality is pretty high. The edit could make this.
Assuming separate lists for fiction and non-fiction.  Interest can peak quickly with good publicity.
